um are brought together on the Fly via

everyone disperses and leaves no
Trace I think that flash mobs are a
demonstration of what technology can do
they're demonstration of uh how you can
use um fun and and a kind of a sense of
being a secret agent on a mission to get
people together in really large numbers
um I think that because the idea of
flash mobs being absurd and being 10
minutes or less sort of means that they
are uh not very great uh vehicles for
expression or for actual you know
creating political change um but I do
think that they are uh an incredibly
powerful demonstration of of what these

in interesting ways um to me the flash
mobs were sort of um more showing what
could be done but that that this this
the um more serious stuff is a Step
Beyond to me flash moms were a kind of
performance art um and and you know they
uh weren't protests uh they certainly
weren't a substitute for protests um
they were
uh a social experiment um they were a
demonstration of what uh the the
technology of sort of Internet chain
emails could do and and text messaging
can do uh and the demonstration of um of
social networks in the way in which
people can you know just through
you know one person forwards it to 10
people and they forward it to 10 people
and before you know it you can gather
really tremendous crowds um and I also
think that they were an important
demonstration to the people who took
part in them where um you know
especially in this kind of era of
Facebook where uh we have these large
communities of quote unquote friends but
our relationships with them are so
virtual and they're so um bound up in uh
you know these very um effect emal or
kind of just purely digital uh uh
transactions where you see a face on a
screen and you send a message or you see
a post on the wall there's something
about flash mobs where uh those
connections are suddenly made really
explicit and really virtual and they
they remind us that uh we are still
people who have bodies and still people
who um who have the ability to to create
change in in in the real physical
world I saw the flash m very much as a
media phenomenon um and you know part of
the thing that I noticed was that you
would have in New York in any given year
and especially during the summertime you
would sort of have uh you know the um
the hot new show of the summer you know
whether it was a comedy show or some or
or some hot new band there would be um
something that would sort of flicker out
through the the sort of hive mind of the
young kind of cultural class in New York
about you know
where where to go and what to do and
what to see uh and part of what I was
trying to Lampoon with the flash mob was
the idea of the next big thing that um
The Flash knobs uh it was like I was
creating the next big thing and I was
saying well I'll tell you what the next
big thing is it's nothing it like let's
all get together for nothing at all um
and that was sort of part of the joke
was a sort of gentle a gentle jab at um
the this New York attitude of of um you
know let's try to find the hot new thing
before everybody else gets there you
know let's let's all Converge on some
new thing uh and make a mob there and so
the flash mob was a very literal
enactment of that uh and in fact part of
why I was so surprised to see the mob
spread to other cities so quickly is
that I I sort of felt like what I was
doing was a quintessentially New York
thing and I was very uh pleasantly
surprised to see people um responding to
the idea in other places as well
probably our biggest flash mop here in
New York was at the Toys R Us in Time
Square um I don't know if you've been to
that Toys R Us but it's a uh you know
this incredible spectacle you know
there's a a working Ferris wheel inside
the store um that sort of is like three
stories tall and um there's a giant
animatronic T-rex dinosaur up on the the
top floor where you know it it has these
lifelike dinosaur movements and it Roars
and uh so we had a flash mob up there
the second floor where everybody
filtered in um secretly and they were
just uh hanging out around you know in
the Barbie Palace or or with the GI Jo's
or that sort of thing and then at the
appointed moment they all rushed this
dinosaur and they got down on their
knees and they cowered behind their
hands like this dinosaur was a terrible
God and this is really just a phenomenal
thing to see you know this is one of the
the biggest um most kind of uh
impressive stores in the whole city and
we basically just shut down the whole
second floor with this impromptu kind of
enacting of of fty to this dinosaur uh
and um it was it was really a kind of
magical moment of uh of of sort of
crystallizing personhood into this you
know it was it um the uh we had sort of
disrupted the flow of this uh of this
store in a way that was that was just
really remarkable to see
a lot of flash mobs uh happen in public
space or they happen in sort of
semi-public space where you're allowed
to come in as uh as someone who's just
you know going to shop for example but
when you try to express yourself in any
way when you try to do anything that's
outside of the so-called prescribed
things that you do in that space then
suddenly you're considered to be a
trespasser suddenly you're considered to
be an interloper you know and I think
one of the reasons why flash mobs were
so powerful for people especially here
in the United States is that we've lost
so much of our tradition of public space
in this country you know that today in
you know the sorts of suburbs where most
people grow up or even here in New York
City or in cities around the country you
know what passes for public space might
be a shopping mall you know that well
that shopping mall is technically
private space but you sort of think well
that's where you go and meet your
friends and that's where you go and you
know walk the the supposed streets of
the mall in order to do your shopping um
of course try to express yourself in
that kind of space and you'll quickly
find out just how uh nonpublic that
space is um and so uh you know a lot
of the fun of The Flash boms was that
because they were 10 minutes or less
usually the police would show up just as
the point that everyone was leaving um
usually and usually they wouldn't be so
mad about it you know the police they
they would have just gotten a call you
know oh there's some weird occurrence
going going on and by the time they got
there you know they would see that
everybody was just having a good time
and they were all leaving and that there
wasn't any threat um but I do think that
it it it managed to be a sort of
intrinsic political statement that way
you know that it was it was very much a
meditation on on public space and what
you can and can't do in a lot of spaces
today the the best way to do it is to
start one of your own you know um it's
it's just a matter of uh of
sending an email out to the people that
you know and telling them to send it
along um you know I I was Anonymous as
the organizer of The Flash Fs in New
York uh in part because I felt like that
um you know the mob would make itself
based on people forwarding the message
around and that even though I would sort
of arbitrarily give it a place to go and
give it something fun to do that really
the um the mobs were leaderless in the
sense that you know I could couldn't
make a mob out of just the people that I
knew I had to rely on uh the networks of
the people I forwarded to and the
networks of the people they forwarded to
and so on in order to get the the group
together um so I think anonymity is a
great um is a great way to do it because
it uh it makes it clear that you know
you're not just organizing a flash mob
for your own you know personal
aggrandisement um it's instead you're
doing an experiment to see you know how
many people you can get to come together
in a physical space and uh and
and when other people pass it along
they're essentially taking on the
project on their they're essentially
taking on the project for themselves and
saying um you know by forwarding the
message along they're in the same
position that you're in they're taking
